fields.Title of Presentation: The Self in Education: From Self-Control to the Growth Mindset
fields.Description/Abstract: The language used to frame and discuss educational issues, both in scientific publication and in everyday talk, shapes broader possibilities for theory and practice. It both enables and limits ways of defining and addressing pedagogical concerns, from general policy to the minutiae of practice. For example, to speak of education as “a process of living and not [as] a preparation for future living” (Dewey, 1897, p. 78) has rather different implications for theory and practice than conceiving it as a form of “human control” exercised through “fundamental laws of change” (Thorndike, 1912, pp. 95, 97).  In this paper, I inquire into the significance of educational vocabularies by focusing specifically on the history of the term “self” in the field of educational psychology.
